texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: author: Major Hayden date: '2022-12-30' summary: 1Password's CLI tool connects via PolicyKit to the 1Password application for authentication, but this isn't the easiest in i3. 🔑 tags:
texts.text: author: Major Hayden date: '2022-12-30' summary: 1Password's CLI tool connects via PolicyKit to the 1Password application for authentication, but this isn't the easiest in i3. 🔑 tags:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 1password
texts.text: 1password

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: i3
texts.text: i3

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: policykit
texts.text: policykit

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: security
texts.text: security

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Bitwarden  became my go-to password manager a few years ago after I finally abandoned LastPass. Once I read the recent news about  stolen password vaults , I was even happier that I made the switch.
texts.text: Bitwarden  became my go-to password manager a few years ago after I finally abandoned LastPass. Once I read the recent news about  stolen password vaults , I was even happier that I made the switch.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: My original password manager from way back in my Apple days was  1Password . It had a great user interface on the Mac and on iPhones, but I found it frustrating to use when I switched to Linux laptops and Android phones.
texts.text: My original password manager from way back in my Apple days was  1Password . It had a great user interface on the Mac and on iPhones, but I found it frustrating to use when I switched to Linux laptops and Android phones.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Lots of people in my Mastodon timeline were singing the praises of 1Password's security and user interface after the recent LastPass news, so I decided to give it another look. It has a great CLI now and the GUI application runs well in Linux. The CLI also connects to the application via  PolicyKit  and it has some helpful plugins for various other CLI tools, like the AWS cli.
texts.text: Lots of people in my Mastodon timeline were singing the praises of 1Password's security and user interface after the recent LastPass news, so I decided to give it another look. It has a great CLI now and the GUI application runs well in Linux. The CLI also connects to the application via  PolicyKit  and it has some helpful plugins for various other CLI tools, like the AWS cli.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I decided to give 1Password another try, but then I ran into a problem with the CLI. 🤔
texts.text: I decided to give 1Password another try, but then I ran into a problem with the CLI. 🤔

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: 🏃 In a hurry?  Go straight to the fix.
texts.text: 🏃 In a hurry?  Go straight to the fix.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Authentication problems
texts.text: Authentication problems

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The 1Password application was up and running and I followed the  documented steps  for enabling Linux authentication for the CLI. However, I still couldn't authenticate:
texts.text: The 1Password application was up and running and I followed the  documented steps  for enabling Linux authentication for the CLI. However, I still couldn't authenticate:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ op item list --vault Private
[ERROR] 2022/12/31 11:26:54 authorization prompt dismissed, please try again
texts.text:
$ op item list --vault Private
[ERROR] 2022/12/31 11:26:54 authorization prompt dismissed, please try again

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The 1Password documentation says that the application will automatically write a polkit action file at
texts.text: The 1Password documentation says that the application will automatically write a polkit action file at

texts.label: code
texts.orig: /usr/share/polkit-1/actions/com.1password.1Password.policy
texts.text: /usr/share/polkit-1/actions/com.1password.1Password.policy

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: to handle the authentication and that file was present:
texts.text: to handle the authentication and that file was present:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ ls -al /usr/share/polkit-1/actions/com.1password.1Password.policy
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 1508 Dec 29 09:48 /usr/share/polkit-1/actions/com.1password.1Password.policy
texts.text:
$ ls -al /usr/share/polkit-1/actions/com.1password.1Password.policy
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 1508 Dec 29 09:48 /usr/share/polkit-1/actions/com.1password.1Password.policy

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: In addition, the PolicyKit daemon is running:
texts.text: In addition, the PolicyKit daemon is running:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ ps aufx | grep polkit
polkitd     1293  0.0  0.0 2692700 26736 ?       Ssl  10:47   0:00 /usr/lib/polkit-1/polkitd --no-debug
$ rpm -qf /usr/lib/polkit-1/polkitd
polkit-121-4.fc37.x86_64
texts.text:
$ ps aufx | grep polkit
polkitd     1293  0.0  0.0 2692700 26736 ?       Ssl  10:47   0:00 /usr/lib/polkit-1/polkitd --no-debug
$ rpm -qf /usr/lib/polkit-1/polkitd
polkit-121-4.fc37.x86_64

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Putting it together
texts.text: Putting it together

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Then I stopped to think about what the system was telling me:
texts.text: Then I stopped to think about what the system was telling me:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 1Password's CLI says that the authentication prompt is being dismissed
texts.text: 1Password's CLI says that the authentication prompt is being dismissed

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: I never saw an authentication prompt
texts.text: I never saw an authentication prompt

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: The PolicyKit daemon is running properly without errors
texts.text: The PolicyKit daemon is running properly without errors

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Running
texts.text: Running

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: But wait, the policykit daemon is only half of what I needed. There needs to be some type of window manager integration to pop up an authentication prompt and I wasn't seeing that prompt.
texts.text: But wait, the policykit daemon is only half of what I needed. There needs to be some type of window manager integration to pop up an authentication prompt and I wasn't seeing that prompt.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: On i3, I use
texts.text: On i3, I use

texts.label: code
texts.orig: lxpolkit
texts.text: lxpolkit

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: for policykit integration and it should have popped up some kind of prompt for me.
texts.text: for policykit integration and it should have popped up some kind of prompt for me.

texts.label: code
texts.orig: lxpolkit
texts.text: lxpolkit

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: is installed:
texts.text: is installed:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ rpm -q lxpolkit
lxpolkit-0.5.5-8.D20210419git82580e45.fc37.x86_64
texts.text:
$ rpm -q lxpolkit
lxpolkit-0.5.5-8.D20210419git82580e45.fc37.x86_64

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Then I noticed something strange. The actual
texts.text: Then I noticed something strange. The actual

texts.label: code
texts.orig: lxpolkit
texts.text: lxpolkit

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: daemon that handles the authentication prompts was not running even though it was configured to automatically start as soon as I logged in:
texts.text: daemon that handles the authentication prompts was not running even though it was configured to automatically start as soon as I logged in:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ rpm -ql lxpolkit | grep autostart
/etc/xdg/autostart/lxpolkit.desktop
$ pgrep lxpolkit
# Nothing here
texts.text:
$ rpm -ql lxpolkit | grep autostart
/etc/xdg/autostart/lxpolkit.desktop
$ pgrep lxpolkit
# Nothing here

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: My default i3 configuration starts all of these automatically with
texts.text: My default i3 configuration starts all of these automatically with

texts.label: code
texts.orig: dex-autostart
texts.text: dex-autostart

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ grep dex ~/.config/i3/config
exec --no-startup-id dex-autostart --autostart --environment i3
texts.text:
$ grep dex ~/.config/i3/config
exec --no-startup-id dex-autostart --autostart --environment i3

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Then I saw the issue at the very end of the
texts.text: Then I saw the issue at the very end of the

texts.label: code
texts.orig: lxpolkit
texts.text: lxpolkit

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: desktop file:
texts.text: desktop file:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ tail /etc/xdg/autostart/lxpolkit.desktop
Comment[tr]=Policykit Kimlik Doğrulama Aracı
Comment[uk]=Агент авторизації Policykit
Comment[zh_CN]=Policykit 认证代理
Comment[zh_TW]=Policykit 身分核對代理程式
Exec=lxpolkit
TryExec=lxpolkit
Icon=gtk-dialog-authentication
Hidden=true
X-Desktop-File-Install-Version=0.26
OnlyShowIn=LXDE;
texts.text:
$ tail /etc/xdg/autostart/lxpolkit.desktop
Comment[tr]=Policykit Kimlik Doğrulama Aracı
Comment[uk]=Агент авторизації Policykit
Comment[zh_CN]=Policykit 认证代理
Comment[zh_TW]=Policykit 身分核對代理程式
Exec=lxpolkit
TryExec=lxpolkit
Icon=gtk-dialog-authentication
Hidden=true
X-Desktop-File-Install-Version=0.26
OnlyShowIn=LXDE;

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The
texts.text: The

texts.label: code
texts.orig: OnlyShowIn=LXDE
texts.text: OnlyShowIn=LXDE

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: means that
texts.text: means that

texts.label: code
texts.orig: dex-autostart
texts.text: dex-autostart

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: will skip it when the environment is set to
texts.text: will skip it when the environment is set to

texts.label: code
texts.orig: i3
texts.text: i3

texts.label: title
texts.orig: The fix
texts.text: The fix

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I copied the desktop file into my local autostart directory and removed the last line:
texts.text: I copied the desktop file into my local autostart directory and removed the last line:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ cp /etc/xdg/autostart/lxpolkit.desktop ~/.config/autostart/
$ tail -n 5 ~/.config/autostart/lxpolkit.desktop
Exec=lxpolkit
TryExec=lxpolkit
Icon=gtk-dialog-authentication
Hidden=true
X-Desktop-File-Install-Version=0.26
texts.text:
$ cp /etc/xdg/autostart/lxpolkit.desktop ~/.config/autostart/
$ tail -n 5 ~/.config/autostart/lxpolkit.desktop
Exec=lxpolkit
TryExec=lxpolkit
Icon=gtk-dialog-authentication
Hidden=true
X-Desktop-File-Install-Version=0.26

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Then I ran
texts.text: Then I ran

texts.label: code
texts.orig: dex-autostart
texts.text: dex-autostart

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: manually to ensure it worked:
texts.text: manually to ensure it worked:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# dex-autostart --autostart --environment i3 --verbose
Autostart file: /home/major/.config/autostart/lxpolkit.desktop
Executing command: lxpolkit
texts.text:
# dex-autostart --autostart --environment i3 --verbose
Autostart file: /home/major/.config/autostart/lxpolkit.desktop
Executing command: lxpolkit

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Success!
texts.text: Success!

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ ps aufx |grep lxpolkit
major      20432  0.0  0.0 393124 12304 pts/3    Sl   11:54   0:00 lxpolkit
texts.text:
$ ps aufx |grep lxpolkit
major      20432  0.0  0.0 393124 12304 pts/3    Sl   11:54   0:00 lxpolkit

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I tried the 1Password command line application one more time...
texts.text: I tried the 1Password command line application one more time...

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: 1Password auth prompt via policykit
texts.text: 1Password auth prompt via policykit

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: It worked! As long as the 1Password application is running and unlocked, I can use the
texts.text: It worked! As long as the 1Password application is running and unlocked, I can use the

texts.label: code
texts.orig: op
texts.text: op

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: CLI tool with my normal Linux system authentication.
texts.text: CLI tool with my normal Linux system authentication.
